sen.j: 横山 安武（よこやま やすたけ、天保14年（1843年） - 明治3年7月26日 (旧暦)（1870年8月22日））は、鹿児島藩の慷慨家。
sen.e: Yasutake YOKOYAMA (1843 - August 22, 1870) was an indignant person who served in Kagoshima Domain.
sen.cmt: 通常、他のwikipediaページでもそうですが、鹿児島藩という正式名称ではなく薩摩藩の通称で通っています。この項目だけが鹿児島藩となっていますが原文通りに訳しています。
sen.e: Yasutake YOKOYAMA (1843 - August 22, 1870) was an indignant person who served in Kagoshima Domain.

He was the forth son of Alihiro MORI.
sen.cmt: 父親の名前の読みが見つかりません。「恕」は「ひろ」と読む場合があるようなので、「ありひろ」と推測しています。
sen.e: He was the forth son of Arihiro MORI.
sen.cmt: 森有恕の読みについては、http://www.shibunkaku.co.jp/biography/search_biography_number.php?number=34110によると「ありひろ」でOKのようです。スペルはArihiroに訂正しました。
sen.e: He was the forth son of Arihiro MORI.

sen.j: 儒者横山安容の跡を継ぎ藩に仕え、後に島津久光に側近として仕える。
sen.e: He succeeded the place of a Confucian Anyo YOKOYAMA to serve for Kagoshima Domain, and later he worked under Hisamitsu SHIMAZU as his close adviser.

He succeeded the place of a Confucian Anyo YOKOYAMA to serve for Kagoshima Domain, and later he worked under Hisamitsu SHIMAZU as his close adviser.

sen.j: そして久光の子に藩外での遊学を勧め、佐賀や山口に同行するが、その際奇兵隊の一部の隊士の脱退騒動が発生し、安武は騒動を報告するため無断で鹿児島に帰国したが、久光に免職された。
sen.e: YOKOYAMA recommended the son of Hisamitsu for traveling to study outside of the domain, and YOKOYAMA accompanied with him to Saga and Yamguchi regions; however, YOKOYAMA was involved with an incident during this trip that some members of the cavalry squad dropped out of the party, and when he went back to Kagoshima for reporting the incident without getting permission of his return, he was dismissed from his position by Hisamitsu.

YOKOYAMA recommended the son of Hisamitsu for traveling to study outside of the domain, and YOKOYAMA accompanied him to Saga and Yamaguchi regions; however, YOKOYAMA was involved with an incident during this trip that some members of the Kiheitai Army dropped out of the party, and when he went back to Kagoshima for reporting the incident without getting permission of his return, he was dismissed from his position by Hisamitsu.
sen.cmt: accompanied with→with削除しました。（文法上）Yamguchi→スペルミスのためYamaguchiに訂正しました。cavalry squad→誤訳のため（「騎兵隊」の意味）Kiheitai Armyに訂正しました。
sen.e: YOKOYAMA recommended the son of Hisamitsu for traveling to study outside of the domain, and YOKOYAMA accompanied him to Saga and Yamaguchi regions; however, YOKOYAMA was involved with an incident during this trip that some members of the Kiheitai Army dropped out of the party, and when he went back to Kagoshima for reporting the incident without getting permission of his return, he was dismissed from his position by Hisamitsu.

sen.j: その後、田口文蔵の門人となる。
sen.e: After his dismissal, he became the disciple of Bunzo TAGUCHI.
After his dismissal, he became the disciple of Bunzo TAGUCHI.
After his dismissal, he became the disciple of Bunzo TAGUCHI.

sen.j: 明治3年（1870年）7月、時弊10箇条を挙げた書を集議院門扉に公示し、津軽藩邸前で屠腹して果てた。
sen.e: In July 1870, YOKOYAMA directly appealed at the gate of Shugiin (the House of Representatives) building with a list of 10 items describing the corrupt practices of those days; after this incident, he committed seppuku and died in front of the residence of Tsugaru Domain.

In July 1870, YOKOYAMA directly appealed at the gate of Shugiin (a legislative body in the early Meiji period) building with a list of 10 items describing the corrupt practices of those days; after this incident, he committed seppuku (suicide by disembowelment) and died in front of the residence of Tsugaru Domain.
sen.cmt: Shugiin (the House of Representatives)→集議院の説明としてthe House of Representatives（=衆議院）が適切かどうか判断しかねるため、a legislative body in the early Meiji periodに訂正しました。seppuku→()内の説明を補足しました。
sen.e: In August 1870, YOKOYAMA directly appealed at the gate of Shugiin (a legislative body in the early Meiji period) building with a list of 10 items describing the corrupt practices of those days; after this incident, he committed seppuku (suicide by disembowelment) and died in front of the residence of Tsugaru Domain.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ歴に変更して最初の日付と合わせました。

sen.j: 明治3年（1870年）7月、時弊10箇条を挙げた書を集議院門扉に公示し、津軽藩邸前で屠腹して果てた。
sen.e: His appeal did not reach the top officials of Meiji government.
